notesStmt.note: Attributed to Henry Neville by Wing.
With a woodcut illustration on the title page. "An inferior reprint of the pamphlet, omitting the woodcut, was made in the 19th century"--Madan.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: An Exact Diurnall OF THE â€¢ ARLIAMENT OF LADYES

Ordered by the LADYES in Parliament, That they declare that Prince Rupert, Lord Digby, Lord Capell, Lord Cottington, Dr. Williams, Mr. Walter, L. Hopton, L. Culpepper, Dr. Duppa, Sir R. Greenvill, L. Jermine, and Major Gen. Vrrey, Have all their Pardons granted to them by this COVRT
may. 6th Printed Anne Dom. 1647.

div.head: AN Exact Diurnall Of the Å¿everall paÅ¿Å¿ages in the PARLIAMENT OF THE LADYES.
From Munday the firÅ¿t ã€ˆ1 span left blankã€‰ till Munday the 8th.
MVNDAY.
div.p: COVNTESSES and other Ladies (on Munday morning early, in a ProÅ¿opopia) being met in Mary Maudlins Hall in Oxford, they firÅ¿t made choyce of their Speaker; and it was agreed by all, that the Lady Oboney Å¿hould have the Chaire, The Lady Rivers was made ChanÅ¿ellor NurÅ¿e Windham High ConÅ¿table, The CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Derby High TreaÅ¿urer, and the CounteÅ¿Å¿e of EÅ¿Å¿ex High Chamberlin.
The Ladies having all taken their places, Mrs. Powell was appointed Cheefe Clerk to the HouÅ¿e, and Mrs. Peele Chaire Lady to the CloÅ¿e Committee, And Moll-Cut-purÅ¿e was made Serjeant at Armes

The firÅ¿t day was wholly taken up in Å¿peeches by the CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Derby, NurÅ¿e Windham, the Lady Rivers, and others, for redreÅ¿Å¿e of greivances, and Execution of JuÅ¿tice againÅ¿t Å¿ome by them charged.

div.head: The CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Derby hir. SPEECH.
div.p: COnÅ¿idering that I owe to the benevolent aÅ¿pects of the Ladies, both my heart, and all reÅ¿pects which may be due unto Å¿o high a Court, whoÅ¿e power Å¿wayes more by love and Armes, then Law. In regard that I was made (by this AÅ¿Å¿embly) Lady High TreaÅ¿urer: I conceive my Å¿elfe obliged to move for redreÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ome abuÅ¿es againÅ¿t our Prelate, by Å¿ome, whoÅ¿e Cowardly and perfidious behaviour, loÅ¿t ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ deÅ¿ignes.

div.head: The Lady Rivers hir SPEECH.
div.p: THis Honourable Lady Speakes Å¿enÅ¿ibly, knowing hir deare Lord to be hereby Å¿orced to remaine in Exile, to pluck GeeÅ¿e, Ducks, Dotterills, and Widgeons, to retaine their Plumes, we may all of us Å¿peake feelingly to this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, my motion is that Prince Rupert, and the reÅ¿t that have beene the cauÅ¿e of it, may be Å¿ent for to come before us.

div.head: NurÅ¿e Windhams SPEECH.
div.p: THeÅ¿e noble Ladyes have moved well: That which I Å¿hallde Å¿ire is, That all Å¿uch who have beene either treacherous to our deÅ¿ignes, or baÅ¿e and cowardly, may be Å¿ent for, and brought to the Barias Delinquents, and here examined before the whole HouÅ¿e.

div.head: The Lady Ohoneys SPEECH.
div.p: I Am amazed at the thoughts of Å¿ome baÅ¿e Å¿pirits, who have betrayed us; But by my conÅ¿ent; let them be Å¿ent for; That both they and all others may know, what it is to treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e on our leuity.
After a long debate about this weighty buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e it was Ordered by the Ladyes, that the Å¿aid buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e be taken into Å¿erious conÅ¿ideration the next day.

div.head: TueÅ¿day.
div.p: THe Ladyes being againe met, debated the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, moved the day before. And Ordered to Å¿end for theÅ¿e Delinquents following, to be brought before them either alive or dead.

list.head: A LiÅ¿t of the Delinquents Å¿ent for PriÅ¿oners to the Ladyes.

div.p: The warrant being delivered to the Sarjant at Armes, Mrs. Mary muÅ¿ters up her witty Merinidons, Å¿ends for and attacheth the Delinquents, whom Å¿he keepes priÅ¿oners, faÅ¿t in Irons, leaÅ¿t they or any of them Å¿hould make eÅ¿cape.

div.head: WedneÅ¿day.
div.p: THe Ladyes being Å¿ate, Moll-CutpurÅ¿e advertiÅ¿ed them, that the priÅ¿oners were all apprehended. Then were they called to the barr. The Lady Speaker Å¿itting in the Cheare, and next to her, on the right hand the Lady ChanÅ¿ellor, and the TreaÅ¿urer, and on the left hand, the Lady High CunÅ¿table, and the Lady Chamberlin, and the reÅ¿t of the Ladyes in order, on the one Å¿ide of the Hall. And on the other, before whom the tr â€¢ mbling priÅ¿oners were brought to the Barr, and the charge brought in by the CloÅ¿e Committee.

1 Prince Rupert was called in, and falling on his knees, heard his charge read againÅ¿t him, that he hath been the cheife cauÅ¿e of their deÅ¿ignes miÅ¿carying by his plundering at Edge-Hill, his wilfulneÅ¿Å¿e at MarÅ¿ton-moore, and his cowardlineÅ¿Å¿e at BoiÅ¿toll. To all which he pleaded not guilty noble Amozons.

2. Then the Lord George Digby was called to the Barr, and charged for a Machivilian, when he was Secretary: A coward when he was Generall, and an AÅ¿Å¿e when he went IriÅ¿h EmpaÅ¿Å¿adour; To which his LordÅ¿hip pleaded not guilty my Ladyes.

3 The Lord Capell was charged for a Plunderer, a Robearier, and a Cow â€¢â€¢ ealer, and by that meanes their cauÅ¿e was diÅ¿paradged, and made odious, as if the Armies intended to make a pray of the people. To all which his LordÅ¿hip pleaded not guilty, and if it pleaÅ¿e your LadyÅ¿hips.

4 The old L. Cottington, (though uery loath to kneele) was forÅ¿ed to Å¿ubmit and here his charge. That he had not onely often vext the Ladyes at Court by croÅ¿Å¿ing their motions, but had put them into many terrible, frights, during the Leagure at Oxford, and at laÅ¿t betrayd them co Å¿ave his owne head, which was never half Å¿o good
as Prince Griffins, or the Calves head, at the Beggers feaÅ¿t. His LordÅ¿hip Å¿aid he was an innocent Lord, and prayed them to pitty his age, and he would never trouble them.

5 Doctor Williams, late Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Yorke, was charged (by a complaint made by the welch Ladyes againÅ¿t him) that he made his coÅ¿en Taffy to leape ditches and Ramplers up and downe, and on both Å¿ides, in England and in Wales: and at laÅ¿t to leape quite away from hir. His LordÅ¿hip would not endure the charge.

6 Mr. Walter was brought to the Barr and charged to be a great diÅ¿gracer of their Å¿ex, and that he laid open his wives InconÅ¿tancy, Å¿o much to the worlds vew, that it extended to the diÅ¿paridgment of Å¿ome members of their AÅ¿Å¿embly, and that for the Å¿ame he was charged to be a grand inÅ¿endiary. To which charge he pleaded he was not guilty of any miÅ¿demeanor.

7 The Lord Hopton was charged, for that when he was Cheife protector of their LadyÅ¿hips hopes to get up an Army again to hold up their Spirits, that his LordÅ¿hip did in a baÅ¿e manner, firÅ¿t fly before Sir Thomas Fairfax in the WeÅ¿t, and at laÅ¿t (without fighting) Å¿urrender all their HorÅ¿es, and Armes. To which he pleaded not guilty, my Honoured Ladies.

8 The Lord Culpepper was charged for a cloÅ¿e Juncto man, and that he was a fomenter of diviÅ¿ions, betweene the Ladies and their HuÅ¿bands; And that he had TraiterouÅ¿ly intiÅ¿ed Prince Charles to go into Sicilie, and Å¿o into France. To which he pleaded not guilty of offence therein.

9 Doctor Duppa is charged for hiding himÅ¿elfe when the Prince was in moÅ¿t need of him; and that he was a falÅ¿e Prophet telling the Ladies of great victories, when they had the greateÅ¿t loÅ¿Å¿es; To which he pleaded nulla Errata.

10 Sir Richard Greenvill was charged for Tyrannicall uÅ¿adge to the Countrie, and that by killing and hanging divers only for revenge and pride, he loÅ¿t the hearts of a great party which otherwiÅ¿e would have held up EpiÅ¿copacie, and Common prayer, May poles, & Morrice-dancing; Wakes, and Love-meetings, which now are laid aÅ¿ide. Sir Richard anÅ¿wered. That he was the Ladies humble Servant, though they Å¿hould hang him every day.

11. The Lord Harry Iermin, was Charged by the Ladies, that his LordÅ¿hip was made all of Complements towards them, not Å¿paring them one drop of help along time, onely had kept himÅ¿elf in quarters
and a farr off, leaving the reÅ¿t, to fight for, or looÅ¿e the EngliÅ¿h Ladyes Liberties, himÅ¿elfe taking care only to Å¿ave his own Å¿kin whole To which his LordÅ¿hip pleaded. Spare mee, moÅ¿t lovely Gallants, I am cleare of harming you.

12. Major Generall Vrrey was brought to the Barr, his charge was for InconÅ¿tancy. the moÅ¿t hatefull thing to the Ladyes, that he deÅ¿erved death; leaÅ¿t the world Å¿hould be troubled with children of his getting to be like the Father To his charge he pleaded, not guilty.
The witneÅ¿Å¿es were ordered to be Å¿ummoned againÅ¿t the next day, and then the whole matter of fact to be examined and debated.

div.head: ThurÅ¿day.
div.p: THe PriÅ¿oners being againe brought before the Ladyes and witneÅ¿Å¿e examined, The Ladyes upon reÅ¿ult of the whole voted them all guilty, and that the next day Iudgement Å¿hould be denounced againÅ¿t every one of them, according to their Å¿everal offences.

div.head: Friday.
div.p: THe Ladyes delivered Iudgement ag â€¢ inÅ¿t the Å¿everall PriÅ¿oners, as followeth.

list.item: 1. Prince Rupert was Sentenced to be faÅ¿t bound to a PoÅ¿t amongÅ¿t Porcupins, and Å¿o to remaine untill he be Å¿tuck to death with their quills.

2. The Lord Georg Digby was condemned to be put into a Den amongÅ¿t all manner of Vipers, and there to live (all the dayes of his life, on Å¿uch Treacle as he Å¿hall make of them. and have no other food.
3 The Lord Capell was adjudged, to be Å¿tripped Å¿tark-naked, (put into the valley of Hubla) to keepe waÅ¿ps and hornets from the hives of the laborious Beesâ–ª

4 The Lord Cottingtons Sentence was to ride perpetuall PoÅ¿t, between Spain and England, upon old decrepit, Å¿tumbling Jades; and croÅ¿Å¿e the Seas in old wether-beaten French Pickero ones, to and fro, all the dayes of his life.
5 The Arch BiÅ¿hop of York was Condemned to Exile in the lake of Lerna, and there to be confined to a Welch Cottage, And get his living by Angling for Frogs out of thoÅ¿e ditches.
6. MaÅ¿ter Walter was adjudged to be baniÅ¿hed the Company of all women, and carried to a Å¿trange land, to gett his living by teaching Apes, to Å¿ing the Note of the EngliÅ¿h Cuckoe.
7. The Lord Hoptons penalty was denounced againÅ¿t him, that his LordÅ¿hip Å¿hould Å¿erve the Cloaca's at the houÅ¿e of Office, all the dayes of his life.

8. The Lord Culpepper was adjudged to be Exiled a BondÅ¿lave for Å¿even yeares into a Stigion Galloy, to record the GhoÅ¿ts that paÅ¿Å¿e over the Lake, and to be fed with browne Bread CruÅ¿ts, and foure fillips on the NoÅ¿e every bit he eats.
9. Doctor Duppaners Å¿enteneed by the Ladyes to Å¿erve the Scouring Woemen at Court, and be fed with the Cookes papers, taken from under the Kings Pies, PaÅ¿ties, and Tartes.

10. Sir Richard Greenvills doome was, to be put into a Cave in the IÅ¿le of Wight, without any light but the glittering of Glo-wormes and Rotten Wood, and there to fight with Ratts, MiÅ¿e, and WeaÅ¿eils. And live upon the prey of thoÅ¿e undermining vermin.

11. The Lord Henry Germin, his Judgement is to be confined to the Land of Pigmyes, to help the Inhabitants to diÅ¿cover the Å¿uttle plots of the Cranes, and Herons; and aÅ¿Å¿ert them againÅ¿t Å¿uch like feirce Birds that would eat them up.
12. Major Generall Vrry his penaltyes to be tyed to a very high Weathercock on the top of a Steeple, and feed only on Flyes and Spyders.

div.p: The Lady Speaker having thus in the name of the whole HouÅ¿e denounced Sentence againÅ¿t the PriÅ¿oners. The Lord Digby (in moÅ¿t Å¿ubmiÅ¿sive manner) prayes for mitigation of his Å¿entences: And Å¿o doth the Lord Iermin, and all the reÅ¿t of the condemned PriÅ¿oners, whoÅ¿e briniÅ¿h teares made the Ladies hearts to relent, And Ordered to conÅ¿ider how to Å¿hew them mercy on the morrow.

div.head: Saterday.
div.p: THe Ladyes being againe Å¿oliÅ¿ited in behalfe of the PriÅ¿oners condemned, to leÅ¿Å¿en thoÅ¿e bitter Å¿entenÅ¿es denounced againÅ¿t them, debated the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; and at laÅ¿t Ordered that a generall Reprive Å¿hould be granted to them all which was done accordingly, to the great joy of all the PriÅ¿oners, and their friends.
